awd_titl_txt: UNS: Non-Optical Detection of Biomolecular Binding Events at Electrical Liquid Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The requested funding is for instruments that will enable development of medical assays inexpensively and accurately. The approach is new and novel, and has the potential to reduce health care cost.


This is a request for two pieces of instrument and equipment that will augment his on going research funded via CAREER. The PI's CAREER proposal was about developing an electrokinetic portable multiplexed biosensing system  that would detect biomolecules at liquid-liquid interfaces. The plan is -  to understand how biomolecular interactions influence the electrical response of a liquid interface; to understand how the physical characteristics of the liquid interface determine the biosensing specificity and sensitivity; and, to develop multiplexed biosensing capabilities and validate the liquid biosensors for disease biomarkers in practical samples. The core idea is to examine a biomolecular-binding event as a perturbing source interfacial polarization, which we can then be detect by measuring interfacial position.  The requested instrument will enable the PI to quantify liquid interfacial position non-invasively in real-time The Broader Impact of the PI's CAREER is to engage awareness in high school students, and via Science Academy program in Baltimore City Middle schools as well as engage underrepresented students in his research lab.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to develop a non-optical method for detecting biomolecular binding interactions in solution without labels. Detection was accomplished using a combination of microfluidics and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). EIS is an electrical technique that measures electrical current across a circuit in response to a known applied voltage. We used this EIS approach to develop a new method for tracking microfluidic flows non-optically.

Our project was motivated by the desire to develop a non-optical approach for detecting biomolecules through tracking the motion of liquid interfaces in electric fields. We created laminar liquid interfaces using microfluidics. In this approach, two fluid streams were driven to flow side-by-side using external pressure. Biosensing was performed by initiating a biomolecular reaction at this interface. To accomplish this, one fluid contained a target analyte and the adjacent flow stream contained a specific binding probe. The interface was subjected to an alternating current (AC) electric field using an array of displacement electrodes positioned across the width of the microchannel. These electrodes served to polarize the fluid interface and force it into motion across the microchannel. We have previously shown that biomolecular binding at this interface significantly alters the degree to which the fluid deflects in an electric field. Therefore, by tracking the position of the deflected interface during exposure to biomolecular binding, interfacial motion can serve as a sensitive transducer to detect biomolecules. Prior to this project, interfacial motion was tracked using confocal microscopy. As such, our biosensing approach was limited to the laboratory and was not yet possible to be performed in a portable setting. This limitation served as the motivation for this funded research.

The objective of this project was to develop a means to non-optically track the interfacial position of the fluid during exposure to an AC electric field. In doing so we would have the capabilities to detect biomolecular binding non-optically without a microscope.

 Funds from the NSF Nanobiosensing program have allowed us to accomplish this objective. We developed new electrode sensors that allow us to measure the EIS of the fluid interface as it moves across the microchannel. We demonstrated that the interfacial position sensitively influences the impedance magnitude, |Z|. Our work now allows us to measure this magnitude (|Z|) and determine the position of the fluid interface non-optically. The results of this project provide a new non-optical tool for measuring microfluidic flows without a microscope, which lowers the barrier for operating microfluidic devices outside the confines of the laboratory and significantly improves the capabilities of our interface-based biosensing platform. Results from this project have been published in a leading sensor journal - Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical 239, 218-225, 2017.

The intellectual merit of this proposed research lies in the innovative strategy to develop label-free methods to monitor biomolecular interactions in solution at liquid interfaces. It explores the potential benefits that the detection of biomolecules in solution phase can offer in terms of portability, cost, and ease of use over traditional biosensing at solid surfaces. Moreover, this research seeks to understand how biomolecular binding interactions influence the electrical behavior of liquid interfaces, and how this can be utilized as an inexpensive and portable biosensing platform. Notably, the proposed biosensing platform is portable, inexpensive, and does not require fluorescent labeling, microscopy or surface immobilization of ligands.

Broader Impact: The development of biosensors and biosensing transducers capable of sensitive, yet inexpensive and portable biomolecular detection is the foundation for point of care diagnostics. This work will likely lead to the integration of liquid-based electrokinetic biosensors into portable biomolecular monitors for use in drug screening, food safety, environmental monitoring, and biopharmaceutical production. This project formed a basis for graduate training in microfluidics and biosensing. Additionally, one undergraduate student also worked on this project. This student is listed as a co-author on the project's published results.


Last Modified: 01/12/2017
Modified by: Zachary R Gagnon
